newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: FEATURE - India's non-tariff barriers dog traders.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - India's non-tariff barriers dog traders.

text.p: While politicians and officials in Dhaka boast of wresting major tariff concessions from New Delhi, businessmen say they still worry about India's tough non-tariff trade barriers.
India recently offered tariff concessions ranging from 25 percent to 50 percent for 513 Bangladeshi products in an effort to narrow its yawning trade gap with its smaller neighbour.
"I am sure that the concessions offered by India to Bangladesh will lead to substantially increased trade flows to India from Bangladesh," Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina said earlier this month.
The tariff cuts are due to take effect next month following ratification by India's parliament, but Bangladeshi businessmen have expressed guarded enthusiasm.

"The tariff concessions in reality won't mean much unless the non-tariff barriers are removed," said Yusuf Abdullah Harun, president of the Federation of Bangladesh Chambers of Comemrce and Industry (FBCCI).

"Definitely the offers can be a breakthrough for Bangladeshi exports. But their (India's) non-tariff restrictions are notorious and can spoil all prospects," said a top official of Dhaka's Metropolitan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (MCCI).
Indian Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda and Foreign Minister I.K. Gujral, said during a recent visit to Dhaka that India would end all non-tariff restrictions on Bangladeshi imports.
Bangladeshi traders remain unconvinced.

"The Indian government's goodwill is unparallelled. But we have seen in the past that what is made by the governments is unmade by their bureaucracy," the MCCI official told Reuters recently, speaking anonymously. "Our fingers are often burnt."
BANGLADESHI COMPLAINTS
Bangladeshi exporters complain that Indian customs officials harrass importers with "rules of origin" and "value addition" requirements.
The MCCI official, who monitors India-Bangladesh trade, cited a recent case where an Indian merchant was heavily penalised for importing car batteries from Bangladesh.
"They (Indian customs) always try to find some flaws and make imports from us repulsive," he said.
India's exports to Bangladesh, growing at an annual rate 20 to 25 percent, reached $1.2 billion in fiscal 1995/96 (July-June) while its imports from Bangladesh were $70 million.
Local trading sources claim another $2.0 billion worth of Indian goods are smuggled into Bangladesh a year, making the country India's fifth largest export source.
Dhaka businessmen are happy, however, that the concession list covers all important products in the highly competitive Indian market.
"It could be a great opportunity for our exports and industry. Leather, melamine and ceramic table wares, ready-made garments, and electric bulbs have tremendous prospects," said the MCCI official.
He estimated Dhaka's exports might grow by a modest $20-25 million annually in the short term, and could reach up to $1.0 billion by the year 2,000 on expansion of production capacity.
LIKELY TO SPUR FOREIGN INVESTMENT
The FBCCI chief sees a salutary impact of the freer Indian market on the inflow of foreign direct investment (FDI).

He said foreign companies hesitant to enter Bangladesh's small market would "jump on having their production bases in Bangladesh if they get the opportunity to enter the huge Indian market of nearly one billion people."
"But again, all depends on how the Indian authorities will use the needles of extra-tariff bars," said an official of MCCI, which represents Bangladesh's organised manufacturing sector.
Private companies here say India has maintained a protective trade regime while taking advantage of the liberalisation in neighbouring countries, particularly Bangladesh and Sri Lanka.
"India's competitiveness is somewhat a myth. They protect their market and benefit from liberalisation in other countries," said the MCCI executive.
He referred to a recent study on competitiveness by MCCI and the Confederation of Indian Industries (CII).

"The study showed as many as 20 major consumer items such as ready made garments, leather products, ceramic wares, bulbs, etc, clearly have a competitive edge over identical Indian products," he said. "We can prove it if they waive the restrictions."
